GARDINER

and spur 'em,

Commotions, uproars, with a general taint

and fight for bitten apples; that no audience,
but

1653.text:
the tribulation of Tower-hill, or the limbs
of

1657.text:
Limehouse, their dear brothers, are able to
endure.

1661.text:
I have some of 'em in Limbo Patrum, and there
they

1664.text:
are like to dance these three days; besides
the

1667.text:
running banquet of two beadles that is to
come.

1672.text:
Chamberlain
Mercy o' me, what a multitude are here!

1675.text:
They grow still too; from all parts they are
coming,

1678.text: As if we kept a fair here!

1681.text:
Where are these porters,
These lazy knaves?

1684.text:
Ye have made a fine hand, fellows:
There's a trim rabble let in: are all these

1689.text: Your faithful friends o' the suburbs?

1692.text:
We shall have
Great store of room, no doubt, left for the

1695.text:
ladies,
When they pass back from the christening.

1698.text:
your honour,
We are but men; and what so many may do,

1702.text:
Not being torn a-pieces, we have done:
An army cannot rule 'em.

1707.text:
If the king blame me for't, I'll lay ye all
By the heels, and suddenly; and on your heads

1713.text:
Clap round fines for neglect: ye are lazy
knaves;

1718.text:
And here ye lie baiting of bombards, when
Ye should do service.

1722.text:
Hark! the trumpets sound;
They're come already from the christening:

1726.text:
Go, break among the press, and find a way
out

1729.text:
To let the troop pass fairly; or I'll find
A Marshalsea shall hold ye play these two

1735.text:
Porter
Make way there for the princess.

1739.text: Stand close up, or I'll make your head ache.

1741.text:
Porter
You i' the camlet, get up o' the rail;

1744.text: I'll peck you o'er the pales else.

1752.text:
Enter trumpets, sounding; then two Aldermen,
Lord Mayor, Garter, CRANMER, NORFOLK with

1759.text:
his marshal's staff, SUFFOLK, two Noblemen
bearing great standing-bowls for the christening-gifts;

1765.text:
then four Noblemen bearing a canopy, under
which the Duchess of Norfolk, godmother, bearing

1771.text:
the child richly habited in a mantle, & c.,
train borne by a Lady; then follows the Marchioness

1778.text: Dorset, the other godmother, and Ladies.

1782.text:
The troop pass once about the stage, and Garter
speaks

1785.text:
Garter
Heaven, from thy endless goodness, send prosperous

1789.text:
life, long, and ever happy, to the high and
mighty

1797.text: Enter KING HENRY VIII and Guard

1799.text:
CRANMER
[Kneeling] And to your royal grace, and the

1804.text:
good queen,
My noble partners, and myself, thus pray:

1810.text:
All comfort, joy, in this most gracious lady,
Heaven ever laid up to make parents happy,

1822.text:
KING HENRY VIII
Thank you, good lord archbishop:

1828.text:
KING HENRY VIII
Stand up, lord.

1830.text: KING HENRY VIII kisses the child

1833.text:
With this kiss take my blessing: God protect
thee!

1837.text: Into whose hand I give thy life.

1840.text:
KING HENRY VIII
My noble gossips, ye have been too prodigal:

1845.text:
I thank ye heartily; so shall this lady,
When she has so much English.

1852.text:
For heaven now bids me; and the words I utter
Let none think flattery, for they'll find

1861.text:
This royal infant--heaven still move about
her!--

1866.text:
Though in her cradle, yet now promises
Upon this land a thousand thousand blessings,

1874.text:
Which time shall bring to ripeness: she shall
be--

1879.text:
But few now living can behold that goodness--
A pattern to all princes living with her,

1887.text:
And all that shall succeed: Saba was never
More covetous of wisdom and fair virtue

1895.text:
Than this pure soul shall be: all princely
graces,

1901.text:
That mould up such a mighty piece as this
is,

1906.text:
With all the virtues that attend the good,
Shall still be doubled on her: truth shall

1914.text:
nurse her,
Holy and heavenly thoughts still counsel her:

1921.text:
She shall be loved and fear'd: her own shall
bless her;

1926.text:
Her foes shake like a field of beaten corn,
And hang their heads with sorrow: good grows

1935.text:
with her:
In her days every man shall eat in safety,

1940.text:
Under his own vine, what he plants; and sing
The merry songs of peace to all his neighbours:

1950.text:
God shall be truly known; and those about
her

1954.text:
From her shall read the perfect ways of honour,
And by those claim their greatness, not by

1965.text:
Nor shall this peace sleep with her: but as
when

1969.text:
The bird of wonder dies, the maiden phoenix,
Her ashes new create another heir,

1976.text:
As great in admiration as herself;
So shall she leave her blessedness to one,

1984.text:
When heaven shall call her from this cloud
of darkness,

1989.text:
Who from the sacred ashes of her honour
Shall star-like rise, as great in fame as

1996.text:
she was,
And so stand fix'd: peace, plenty, love, truth,

2006.text:
terror,
That were the servants to this chosen infant,

2011.text:
Shall then be his, and like a vine grow to
him:

2016.text:
Wherever the bright sun of heaven shall shine,
His honour and the greatness of his name

2023.text:
Shall be, and make new nations: he shall flourish,
And, like a mountain cedar, reach his branches

2033.text:
To all the plains about him: our children's
children

2038.text: Shall see this, and bless heaven.

2041.text:
KING HENRY VIII
Thou speakest wonders.

2044.text:
CRANMER
She shall be, to the happiness of England,

2048.text:
An aged princess; many days shall see her,
And yet no day without a deed to crown it.

2057.text:
Would I had known no more! but she must die,
She must, the saints must have her; yet a

2067.text:
virgin,
A most unspotted lily shall she pass

2072.text:
To the ground, and all the world shall mourn
her.

2077.text:
KING HENRY VIII
O lord archbishop,

2079.text:
Thou hast made me now a man! never, before
This happy child, did I get any thing:

2085.text:
This oracle of comfort has so pleased me,
That when I am in heaven I shall desire

2091.text:
To see what this child does, and praise my
Maker.

2096.text:
To you, my good lord mayor,
And your good brethren, I am much beholding;

2100.text:
I have received much honour by your presence,
And ye shall find me thankful.

2105.text:
Lead the way, lords:
Ye must all see the queen, and she must thank

2110.text:
ye,
She will be sick else.

2112.text:
This day, no man think
Has business at his house; for all shall stay:

2117.text: This little one shall make it holiday.

2123.text:
EPILOGUE
'Tis ten to one this play can never please

2128.text:
All that are here: some come to take their
ease,

2132.text:
And sleep an act or two; but those, we fear,
We have frighted with our trumpets; so, 'tis

2140.text:
clear,
They'll say 'tis naught: others, to hear the

2143.text:
city
Abused extremely, and to cry 'That's witty!'

2148.text:
Which we have not done neither: that, I fear,
All the expected good we're like to hear

2155.text:
For this play at this time, is only in
The merciful construction of good women;

2161.text:
For such a one we show'd 'em: if they smile,
And say 'twill do, I know, within a while

2170.text:
All the best men are ours; for 'tis ill hap,
If they hold when their ladies bid 'em clap.

2179.text:
End of Act V
End of Henry VIII
